title: Lipomatous mass
diagnosis_topic: Lipomatous mass — lipoma vs atypical lipomatous tumor / well-differentiated liposarcoma (WDLPS).
setup_script: “A 57-year-old man is referred to your clinic for a slowly enlarging, painless lump on the medial aspect of his left thigh that he first noticed 18 months ago.”No additional vitals, history, exam details, or imaging are provided until the resident requests them. 3.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Step 1 — History Gathering- Expected resident actions
dynamic_flow.reply: Clarify growth rate, pain, trauma, constitutional symptoms, family history of soft-tissue tumors.-
“Mass grew from ‘marble’ to ‘plum’; no pain/trauma, no B-symptoms, no relevant family history.”- Rescue prompt: “Anything else you’d like to ask?”- Critical failure: Omits growth-rate assessment.
Request vitals and targeted extremity exam (location, depth to fascia, mobility, neurovascular status, regional nodes).-

“Vitals normal. 5 × 4 cm soft but deep, minimally mobile intramuscular mass in the adductor compartment; skin normal; no inguinal nodes.”- Rescue prompt: “Would you like to examine the mass?”- Critical failure: Neglects compartment or nodal exam.
Order MRI with/without contrast, including fat-suppressed sequences.-

“MRI: 5.4 cm intramuscular fatty lesion with thick (>2 mm) septa, focal nodular non-adipose areas, mild enhancement.”- Rescue prompt: “Do you want any imaging?”- Critical failure: Chooses ultrasound only and stops.
Interpret MRI as suspicious for atypical lipomatous tumor/WDLPS; plan core-needle biopsy along the future surgical corridor.-
Pathology returns atypical lipomatous tumor/WDLPS with MDM2 amplification.- Rescue prompt: “How will you obtain tissue?”- Critical failure: Excisional biopsy via transverse incision.
Order chest CT for staging (metastases uncommon but guideline-concordant).-
Chest CT is clear.- Rescue prompt: “Any staging?”- Critical failure: Omits metastatic workup.

Offer wide local excision (1–2 cm margins) for WDLPS; contrast with marginal excision or observation if benign lipoma. Discuss limb-sparing approach, specimen orientation, drain use.- Examiner stance: Accepts appropriate plan.- Rescue prompt: “What operation will you offer?”- Critical failure: Treats as simple lipoma and plans shell-out.

Longitudinal incision; resect tumor with a cuff of fascia/muscle; avoid capsular rupture; orient specimen with tags (proximal/distal/deep).- Examiner stance: Accepts detailed, oncologic technique.- Rescue prompt: “Describe your operative plan.”- Critical failure: Leaves tumor capsule behind.

MRI and chest imaging every 6 months for 5 years; present at sarcoma tumor board; consider adjuvant RT if margins <1 cm.- Examiner stance: Accepts comprehensive plan.- Rescue prompt: “How will you follow him?”- Critical failure: No surveillance strategy.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If biopsy shows benign lipoma, offer marginal excision in clinic vs observation; explain reasoning and risks.- Examiner stance
dynamic_flow.reply: Accepts clear differentiation.- Rescue prompt: “How would benign pathology change things?”- Critical failure: Cannot articulate difference between WDLPS and lipoma management.
Concise summary; counsel on recurrence (<10%) and dedifferentiation risk (<5%). Examiner ends case.- Critical failure: Cannot synthesize a final plan.

critical_decision_points: Order MRI (fat-suppressed sequences) to characterize a lipomatous lesion.
Perform core-needle biopsy along the future surgical corridor prior to definitive excision.
Distinguish operative approach: wide local excision for WDLPS vs marginal excision/observation for lipoma.
Engage multidisciplinary sarcoma tumor board and establish surveillance.
resident_feedback_template: Strengths (examples):- Recognized MRI features concerning for WDLPS.- Selected core-needle biopsy correctly.Areas for Improvement (examples):- Provide precise specimen orientation tags.- Quote recurrence and dedifferentiation risks during counseling.- Clarify staging CT indications.Suggested Reading:- NCCN Soft Tissue Sarcoma Guidelines (current).- “MRI Criteria for Lipomatous Tumors,” Radiology.- ACS Video: Atypical Lipomatous Tumor Resection.
